attributes.comment:
The proposed fee increases are unacceptable and unjustifiable for many reasons
(below). USCIS has made no efforts at cost containment and fee increases cannot
be justified until that is done. A system wide analysis by GAO identification
of failures and recommendations for improvements in USCIS should be accomplished
first.
The justifications are those same given over the past 20 years with the same
(unkept) promises, because the CIS/ICE/CBP have no enforced benchmarks, no
compromise with opponents/critics/consumers, and no standards-including
realistic assessments of risks. In Wayne County, Michigan government, if a
decision is not made on a permit within 60 days, then it is automatically
granted. However, in USCIS, if an application is not adjudicated in 5-10 years,
it lingers unattended, even if repeated inquiries are made to the officer and
their supervisor. (I currently have a case where an I-130 remains
unadjudicated for 10 years.) Decision-making is avoided, not managed. There
appear to be no deadlines whatsoever. This leads to additional inquiries and
senseless applications or maneuvers by applicants to move cases, which then adds
to the work burden and extends delays. This procrastination even extends to
just scheduling interviews: once an application is submitted, there should be an
enforced calendar to at least given an interview date! USCIS should have a rule
set for it to decide I-130, I-751s within 1 year: this is not an impossible task
to decide if a couple is married, yet it dares not set any limits for its own
faults. Only if actual deadlines are imposed will USCIS officers move cases
through the system, as was done in the asylum offices with their 180 day deadline.
A business would advertise to its customers when to expect results. USCIS
does not guarantee anything; it has no regular mechanism to meet with its
?consumers? (attorney groups and non-profit agencies) on specific problems or
cases. I have never seen USCIS consult its consumers and ask for and really
consider their suggestions on its proposals. Had this been done, the waste of
millions of hours of staff time with the NSEERS interviews would not have
diverted attention from more productive efforts. This was widely predicted by
immigration practitioners to be futile but went ahead anyways.
There is no prioritization of cases and devotion of valuable human resources
to those first. USCIS and ICE act as if they will interview extensively and
prosecute fully every single case or minor human or technical transgression. As
an example, the Detroit District Office interviews I-130 applications of persons
married for several years, with children of their marriage, and who have
submitted extensive documentation of their marriage, after they have already
approved the I-130! Further, Detroit?s adjudication section interviews couples
married sometimes up to 10 years! Couples with children of their marriage are
also interviewed. This should only be done in extremely rare instances instead
of current practice. There is not a high incidence of fraud of married couples
with biological children of their marriage (by inherent definition, this is
impossible) justifying such tactics. It raises costs by squandering
interviewing time available to the bureau.
Because there is no standard and risk-assignment to low priority, USCIS
frequently asks for RFEs- Requests for Further Evidence. This should not be
used in low priority cases as it only results in augmenting the voluminous
amount of documents being dumped by applicants and their
attorneys/representatives. Most practitioners I know overdocument all
applications because so many are returned for more and more evidence. There
seems to be no parameters when there is too much information for officers to digest.
There is an insistence on impossible misuse of human resources under the guise
of 100% total security (which is unattainable in human affairs; ie the waste of
the NSEERS interviews). All branches engage in useless litigation (or refer for
litigation), until they are overburdened to breaking with cases: Detroit ICE
would not agree to send back routine and uncomplicated I-485 adjustments from
the Immigration Court to USCIS until the past month, in spite of internal Memos
from Washington to this effect!
Additionally, the imposition of the entire burden of the costs of all
components of the system upon the paying consumers is a default tax on family
and labor-based applications by the public and Congress so that we do not pay
for the security or values we purport to hold (for example, we should accept to
support the asylum system which is a national core value and interest).
Excessive security checks are unfunded mandates passed on to immigrant applicants.
This fee increase is even able to be proposed because there are no market
forces or internal factors to force efficiency. Finally, the fee increases will
increase lack of documentation of persons currently present in our communities
because applications will be unaffordable for many families. Many of our
clients now have to choose which application they can afford because the high
fees and their ancillary fees (for medical exams, translations, express mailing
to meet deadlines, etc.).
Personal insecurity and feelings are allowed to enter into decisions of USCIS
and ICE officers who to ?prosecute?: DNA tests (costing applicants up to $800!
in extra costs) are demanded more and more, even for applicants married for 3-4
years. As officers have said: ?You are lying. That is not your child.? Or ?3
kids doesn?t mean this is a marriage.?!! These are not rational examination of
facts. Children of a marriage does indicate a bona fide marriage.
The citizens of the United States have a public interest in keeping most
residents legal and documented, away from being forced into the underground
systems and economie because they cannot afford to become citizens or legal
residents. This is done by a well-functioning, data-driven, and humane system.
It is not done by forcing vulnerable people to pay for all costs of public
order and efficiency. We should accept that our country should pay some
reasonable costs to underwrite our government functions.
